intro: Malvastrum scabrum var. amblyphyllum, commonly known as the narrow-leaf mallow, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It features slender, upright stems covered in soft, woolly hairs, and its leaves are typically narrow and lance-shaped with a serrated margin. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in dry, rocky habitats. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive and ornamental species within the Malvaceae family.
